sections.heading: 1 Introduction
sections.text: The language of the epistemic specification originally proposed in (Gelfond and Przymusinska 1991), (Gelfond and Przymusinska 1993), (Gelfond 1994), and (Gelfond 1991) is an extension of the language of response programs by modal operators K and M to represent beliefs of the agent, who is able to perform introspection in the presence of multiple beliefs. Intuitively, it is assumed that it uses KF to designate a proposal F that is true in some beliefs of the agent. This extension is useful in discussing its application to the formalization of sound thinking. sections.heading: 4.1 Conformant Planning
sections.text: Consider the planning problem with several possible starting states, which makes it much more difficult to find a so-called safe plan that enforces the goal from each starting state. (Eiter et al. 2003) gives three safety conditions to verify whether a plan is safe: 1. the actions of the plan are executable at the respective stages of execution; 2. at each stage, the execution of the respective actions of the plan always leads to a certain legal state of the plan; and 3. the goal is true in each possible state if all steps of the plan are successfully executed. Here, we consider a trace of the effects of executing an action sequence as a belief, so we can intuitively encode these safety conditions in epistemic specification constraints. We use non-executable actions, contradictory, to determine that a state is illegal, success, to sign a state that meets the goal, and the goal (m) to denote the state that is reached after a certain number of m.

sections.heading: 4.2 Constraints Satisfaction
sections.text: In some situations, limitations of variables are associated with epistemic characteristics, that is, the value of a variable is influenced not only by the values of other variables, but also by all possible values of other variables. Here, we demonstrate the use of ESmodels to solve such limitation problems based on a dinner problem: • if Checkov is not allowed to participate, Jim participates: − not checkove. • if Jim is not allowed to participate, Bones will participate: − not jim. • if only one of Jack and Mike will participate: − not mike. mike: − not mike. mike: − not jack. • if Jack must participate, Uhura will participate: − Kjack. • if Uhura cannot participate, then scotty.

sections.heading: 5 Conclusion
sections.text: ESmodels is an epistemic specification solver designed and implemented as an experimental platform to investigate semantics, language, associated thought algorithms, and possible applications of epistemic specifications. An essential feature of this solver is that its language is more compact than that defined in literature, but is capable of representing many subjective literals through a set of transformation rules. Furthermore, this solver can compute worldviews under gel funds of new definition, while the language presented by Zhang in (Zhang 2007) and Watson in (Watson 1994) is based on the early definition of epistemic specifications. Furthermore, we find the compact coding of compliant planning problems and constraint satisfaction problems in the epistemic specification language, which primarily demonstrates the potential of ESmodels in applications.

metadata.abstractText: (To appear in Theory and Practice of Logic Programming (TPLP)) ESmodels is designed and implemented as an experiment platform to investigate the semantics, language, related reasoning algorithms, and possible applications of epistemic specifications. We first give the epistemic specification language of ESmodels and its semantics. The language employs only one modal operator K but we prove that it is able to represent luxuriant modal operators by presenting transformation rules. Then, we describe basic algorithms and optimization approaches used in ESmodels. After that, we discuss possible applications of ESmodels in conformant planning and constraint satisfaction. Finally, we conclude with perspectives.
